title: What can you do with a degree in PPE? - Quora

response.answer_text: No - I wouldn’t say so. (Disclaimer: my first degree was PPE.) You do pay a price in in-depth knowledge, because you only have time to do a part of what your friends doing “pure” P, P, or E have to do. I felt this when I came to be a research student, because I had absolutely zero idea about what was going on in some research semiars. On the other hand, you do end up with a breadth that they might lack. More generally, I’m deeply suspicious of the idea that we might call any degree useful or useless, because I don’t think that utility is the right lens with which to examine education. Most humanities degrees - hell, most degrees in any discipline that isn’t explicitly vocational - are “useless” in some sense. But they are a sign that you’re able to think in a certain kind of way about the world, and to sustain that thought at a certain level. Not all value is in utility. The one warning-klaxon about PPE, and PPE from a particularly old English university whose name begins with a vowel, is that it does appear to churn out a disproportionately large number of inexplicably cocky sociopaths and mainline them into the political class.

It depends on one’s perspective. Is any college education useless? For those who do not value education, yes, but to those of us who believe that no education is useless, no. But from a more tangible point of view, a PPE degree is very useful for individuals who intend on going to law school, for aspiring politicians, for those who wish to pursue graduate studies in Economics or Political Science, and assuming one attends an elite college/university like and Claremont McKenna, Duke, Michigan-Ann Arbor, Penn, Princeton, Wesleyan etc…a PPE major with a good GPA (over 3.7) should be able to get a job at an Investment Bank or Management Consulting firm.
